instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the characterization of organic compounds, metabolites, small molecules, and phytochemicals derived from Mangifera indica L.?
Output: Proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) signals were used in the characterization of organic compounds, metabolites, small molecules, and phytochemicals derived from Mangifera indica L.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the characterization of organic compounds, metabolites, small molecules, and phytochemicals derived from Mangifera indica L.?
Output: Fourier transform spectra were manually corrected for phase and baseline distortions in the characterization of organic compounds, metabolites, small molecules, and phytochemicals derived from Mangifera indica L.

instruction: What metric was chosen to assess the metabolic differences between wetland (WL) and dryland (DL) mango in the characterization of organic compounds, metabolites, small molecules, and phytochemicals derived from Mangifera indica L., and how far can this metric go in revealing their discriminations?
Output:
The metric chosen to assess the metabolic differences between wetland (WL) and dryland (DL) mango was global target profiling investigation of phytochemicals and inhibitors using proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) signals. This method allowed for the identification and characterization of fifty metabolites, including xanthones, phenolic acids, fatty acids, flavonoids, and amino acids. 

This metric can go a long way in revealing the discriminations between WL and DL mango as it provides a comprehensive analysis of the organic compounds, metabolites, small molecules, and phytochemicals derived from Mangifera indica L. By comparing the metabolomic profiles of WL and DL mango, the study was able to uncover metabolic differences associated with fertilization, biotic and abiotic stress, and oxidative stress metabolisms. This information can help in understanding the unique metabolic pathways and impacts of mango fruits grown in different environments.

instruction: What machine learning models were used in the analysis of the metabolic differences between wetland and dryland mango in the study examining the relationship between Mangifera indica L and dietary-induced metabolic homeostasis?
Output: PCA, PLS-DA, and OPLS-DA score plots were used in the analysis of the metabolic differences between wetland and dryland mango in the study examining the relationship between Mangifera indica L and dietary-induced metabolic homeostasis.

instruction: Can spectroscopic methods be used to characterize the organic compounds, metabolites, small molecules, and phytochemicals derived from Mangifera indica L. in the study examining the relationship between wetland and dryland Mangifera indica L and their impact on dietary-induced metabolic homeostasis?
Output: Yes, spectroscopic methods, specifically proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) signals, can be used to characterize the organic compounds, metabolites, small molecules, and phytochemicals derived from Mangifera indica L. In the study examining the relationship between wetland and dryland Mangifera indica L and their impact on dietary-induced metabolic homeostasis, a global target profiling investigation of phytochemicals and inhibitors in Mangifera indica L. was performed using 1H NMR signals. This spectroscopic method allowed for the identification and characterization of fifty metabolites, including xanthones, phenolic acids, fatty acids, flavonoids, and amino acids.
